br.com.summa.sol.util

Class Lists

  • java.lang.Object
    • br.com.summa.sol.util.Lists

  • public final class Lists
extends Object
    Convenience class for working with Lists.
    Author:
    Einar Saukas

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static <T> T first(List<T> list)
      Obtain the first element from a list, or null if the list is null or empty.
      static <T> T last(List<T> list)
      Obtain the last element from a list, or null if the list is null or empty.
      static <T> Iterable<List<T>> split(Iterator<T> it, int subsize)
      Breaks data into smaller sublists with the specified (maximum) size.

      Instead of allocating everything in memory at once, this variant will just allocate one sublist at a time, while data is iterated, thus this variant is especially useful for processing very large amounts of data that may not even fit in memory (while reading from file or database for instance).

      Typical usage:
      static <T> List<T>[] split(List<T> list, int subsize)
      Breaks list into smaller sublists with the specified (maximum) size.

      Typical usage:
      static <T> void swap(List<T> list, int i, int j)
      Swaps content of specified positions in a list.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

        Obtain the first element from a list, or null if the list is null or empty.

        public static <T> T last(List<T> list)

      • split

        public static <T> List<T>[] split(List<T> list,
                  int subsize)
        Breaks list into smaller sublists with the specified (maximum) size.

        Typical usage: 
         List all = ...
 for (List sub : Lists.split(all, 20)) {
     ...
 }

      • split

        public static <T> Iterable<List<T>> split(Iterator<T> it,
                          int subsize)
        Breaks data into smaller sublists with the specified (maximum) size.

        Instead of allocating everything in memory at once, this variant will just allocate one sublist at a time, while data is iterated, thus this variant is especially useful for processing very large amounts of data that may not even fit in memory (while reading from file or database for instance).

        Typical usage: 
         for (List sub : Lists.split(all.iterator(), 20)) {
     ...
 }

      • swap

        public static <T> void swap(List<T> list,
            int i,
            int j)
        Swaps content of specified positions in a list.
